reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game will make you start out on easy because of the reviews. You might think all of these reviewers suck at gaming and should jump of a bridge for sucking this hard at a 2D game. Well that's what i thought.

You'll start out as a man running around sucking up dirt, trees, grass and other junk. Once you got that outof the way you will start killing everything that moves, assuming every live thing in a game is hostile. You're having a great but confusing time.

Next you'll start crafting stuff, a shotgun, a few wooden blocks and probably a turret or two. Then night starts to fall.

You don't think much of it so you'll just continue making yourself a little cottage. The night slowly grows darker.

It is pitch black, several enemies try to attack you and seem to be breaking through your new house! You fight them off with your shotgun and the sun rises again. It sure was one hell of a night.

The next day you start looking for the materials and resources you need to make the next thing you want, maybe armor or a flashlight. You encounter new animal species and annihilate them on the spot.

Night falls and you rush back to your half destroyed home, quickly patch up the holes and get ready for another group of enemies. They won't catch you off guard this time.

You see the enemies coming, your turrets starts to shoot and off you go fighting for your life once again. You notice the new species you encountered seems to have joined the enemy army, but no fair match for your skill!

Sun rises once again and you rush out to collect and explore, ignoring the fact that you nearly died last night because you never had a second to look at your health bar. Time to annihilate new radioactive animals for pleasure and resource to get yourself a brand new shiny gun. Rather quickly sunset kicks in once again.

Night has fallen and you're starting to lean back a little bit, assuming you'll see victory again. Many many more enemies come. The easy blue flying things and the dog-like kanines don't appear, but instead red flying beasts drilling through your house in a fraction of a second, feral beasts running at you, your turrets all destroyed almost in an instant and you surrounded by enemies, when suddenly...

Everything stops. The foes charging at you casualy roam around the area. Then you realize you're not moving. Words appear on the screen saying: you are dead. You are dead.

You ♥♥♥♥ed up easy mode on the third night. You retry from the morning of day three trying to get more turrets, a better gun, healing kits, yet still you fail at night. You can't make it past night three.

This game is hard. Peaceful mode makes enemies harmless, easy mode rips your clothes off, bends you over and ravages your rear, tearing you a fist size dilation only to call you out for the ♥♥♥♥♥ you are and leaves you to rot in a ditch.

It'll take me some serious effort to learn how to not fail as quickly as i did.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

========================================

Vince Rowe ReviewsSaving The Industry One Game At A Time!

[YouTube Link]   [Curation Link]

========================================


Think Terraria and Tower Defence and you get this game! An amazing little Side-Scroller Sandbox that's so cheap you just can't pass it up!
Verdict - 7.3/10Scroll to the bottom for an Overall



Sandbox - 9/10:
The sandbox in this game is pretty much identical to any other Mine and Craft game out there. You need to mine resources in order to build a better Pickaxe (Or in this case a Gravity Gun?) which you can then use to dig up even higher tier resources to once again build a better Pickaxe (Sorry, Miniaturizor!). However, even though it may be identical it doesn't mean it's bad, it works well so why fix something that's not broken? The actual landscape itself - the stuff you'll be mining - is pretty bare at the moment. There's only two blocks in the actual world; Dirt and Stone (As far as I've dug at least) and I've only come across a few minerals and co.; Iron, Coal and Aluminium, with a couple of essentials dropped from monsters. Other than the caverns and the mountainous area there isn't really much that tells the landscape apart - which is a bit of a shame. Surprisingly, this game has really well made water physics, it rains (A lot!), the water builds up on the surface and pretty much floods everything, after a while it will get absorbed into the ground again sinking into the earth. It's extremely dynamic and really adds to the feel of the world. Unlike typical Sandbox games the Saving system in this game is different - you revert back to your last save instead of respawning.


Combat - 8/10:
Whilst the weapons are limited there's a pretty cool thing you can do with them, they launch the player back when fired - some more than others - and when you're in the air you can go flying. It's great to use the shotgun as a little 'jet-pack boost' and makes the movement of the game flow really well. As I mentioned before; this game has a high emphasis on Base Defence, every night you'll be attacked by monsters which not only can kill you but also break your entire base while they're at it. You can build turrets to help protect your base (Which for some reason they don't try to attack) which are alright but nothing great. The game can get very difficult, especially if you don't know what you're doing (I recommend you read the Quick Help" section before you start)
date: there are a couple of Cheese Tactics you can do but I won't spoil them for you
recommended:
Sandbox games are meant for exploring!


Graphics - 7/10:
The graphics look a little tacky but the reason I've given it a 7 is because they remind me of the old Newgrounds days where almost every single game looked like this. It brought some fond memories of some great games and it may do the same for you.


Audio - 5/10:
The game sounds are alright at best
hoursPlayed: there aren't many things in this game that actually make sound - other than your Gun and the monsters shooting at you. If it wasn't for the great background music I would have rated it much lower. The game lacks ambience
voteText:
and as a result really lacks any real atmosphere. The background music may be good but there definitely needs to be more tracks too.


Overall - 7.3/10
I've had a great load of fun with this game and for £2 (Or $3) it's an absolutely steal (Price will increase over time to £8 (Or $12) - get it while it's cheap!). Whilst it may have some bad points
helpfulPercent:
it's still early days and I hope the developers use Early Access to it's fullest and make the true potential of this game a reality.



Gameplay and Commentary:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DWVXKzPnmgc


Link to my YouTube Channel.
Link to my Twitter Page.
{LINK REMOVED} Link to my Blog.
Link to my Curations."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dig or Die may seems like just another Terraria clones, but underneath the similar mechanics, it is quite a different beast. Its unique mechanics sets it apart from Terraria, and so it is worthy of attention even from Terraria veterans.

The two prominent unique mechanics are: liquid and structural physics. Water not only flows down and fills up space, it exerts pressure to surrounding blocks. Building blocks have structural strength, so they can crumble under pressure. No longer can you dive into the ocean, dig a chamber, create a one block thick seal, and 'mine' the water out to start a dry underwater tunnel. Do that in this game, and the sealing blocks will crumble and your tunnel will be flooded, just as it would in real life.

Structural integrity will also apply to buildings. You will not be able to create a high one block wide tower with platforms on the side, or that stair structures you used so many times in the other games, because your lower blocks would crumble under the weight. A long one block bridge, highway in the sky? Snap! You get the idea.

This game is pretty much under the development, so you will be able to learn these and other features as the game develops. By the time this game came out of Early Access, you will be master at managing water pressure and structural integrity.

I will give this game a score of 8/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alpha games are tough to rate as they are in progress but so far this is a 9/10 for me. I feel as this gets closer to release it will be a 10/10.

Pros:
- Fun graphics (guy jumps like old school megaman)
- Lots of content. (tons of varied enemies, bosses, etc)
- Zero bugs. game never crashes, solid physics engine, water behaves rationaly, etc
- Fun progression. No grinding, just fun exploring. You can not kill new types of enemies to keep the game from progressing to harder levels if you feel in over your head.
-  It's like terraria and Craft the World, with biomes and underwater bases. If you like that type of game this will be most enjoyable for you.
- Price/Value. Right now the game is $4.99 which is an incredible value for what you get.
- Lovely music/sound effects
- Great base defense and tower defense type setup.

Cons: (being picky as this game is pretty flawless)
- The ships computer in the beginning of the game kinda cheats (scans) and tells you where to find everything, if you want a challenge don't listen to him.
- The overcharge cannon has such a high kickback you keep donking your head and sometimes die.
- So many enemies come at night digging at you that you frequently create large underground spaces. Would like the AI to better use existing passages and not dig the entire world up trying to get at you. Just bugs me having a base floating there with no rock or passages around it.

I dunno maybe it's because I just got done playing Skyshines Bedlam, which was $20 and had 1/16th the content this $5 game has and also was a complete steaming pile of ♥♥♥♥, I'm now biased. But Dig or Die is an absolute delight to play and incredibly fun. I'm completely hooked and haven't had this much fun in ages. I haven't been this excited about a game since Ori and The Blind Forest. You know when it's hard, but not so hard you say screw this" and you just stay up till the wee hours of the morning playing it? That's the type of addicting game this is. Whether it's prefecting you underwater base and getting your safety airlocks in place
date: or building a rikity bridge across a chasm trying to discover new riches
recommended: the game is constantly fun. I can't say enough good things about it.\n\nWith so many ealry access games out there ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off with bugs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of these reviews don't really say why this game is a hidden gem. The developer really deserves the money he gets from this- 5$ gets you more than what you pay for. This isn't a game for everybody, though. It requires lots of planning and management to survive at harder difficulties, but on easy and normal you can be a bit more relaxed. It's a somewhat short game, but what do you expect from early access? The developer takes suggestions on how the game could be better or what items would be cool, so if you feel like this game is missing one amazing item, just say so in the discussion thread!

Exploration and material gathering is needed, which can get tedius at times, but you'll pretty much be constantly on your toes with enemies you can easily take out, but doing so will kill you at nighttime. The fact that you have to worry about night makes you have to plan out your adventures carefully and sparingly. Returning home early is better than returning later at night and dying.

A major fun-factor is how you can boost your jumps and movements just by shooting your plasma weapons (Shotgun is best for this) in the opposite direction when you jump, effectively using the knockback to get to hard-to-reach places, for fighting tactics (I love to just boost above a firefly, fall down and just blast that sucker straight into the ground) and to reduce fatal fall damage to nothing.

Water is a very restricting factor in this game- at one point in time you'll have your main cave blocked out by water, causing you to find the source of the problem and plug it up or plan out how you can use your time sparingly underwater unless you want to meet an untimely death. Even your base is prone to floods if you don't plan it out carefully!

Now the enemies are something else. Want a new miniaturizor that will mine things faster? Well, you're going to have to prepare yourself, because that firefly you need to kill for it sure isn't going to go easy on you. Need some aluminum, but don't want to die by these tough enemies at nighttime? Well, you're going to have to move around them or avoid them outright. Running away is always an option, but make sure they don't dig out a path towards you right when you think you're safe.

Defense is fun as hell. You'll spend a lot of time figuring out what turrets work best in what areas. More area coverage means less enemies your turrets have to deal with at a time, but that means more management and costs for keeping them up- and by that, I mean that enemies will target your turrets and go full kamakazi if they so choose, getting at least a couple shots off your turret in the hopes that their friends will take it out.

The music is also really nice. The nighttime music is upbeat while the daytime music is nice and chill.  There are a lot of different tracks, which reduces repetitiveness by quite a bit.

Now here's the big factor- replay ability. It's a sandbox game, so this is an extremely important in buying it. I'm going to be honest here: This game is straightforward and very lenient. After a couple of playthroughs, you'll know exactly what to do after you get this item and the game will get somewhat boring because the enemies feel similar like the fireflies. The only time the replay ability shines is trying out different base designs and the world regeneration, but other than that, there's nothing too special about it.

So overall, a 7/10 for an early access game. The game gets boring after a little bit, which is something the dev should focus on a bit more when he can. The first time experiencing might be a bit confusing, but fun and interesting. The graphics aren't too special, but they're getting a makeover in v0.2, so I'm excited for that. The weapons are diverse and fun, but the only time you get really fun weapons is when there's nothing much left to do in the game. I just love how unique this concept is, and I'm excited to see how this game will develop in time. The developer seems to be constantly updating it, which will in turn make this game cost more, but for now this game is worth it! After all, this is still in early access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game that seems to have watched what people didn't like about other sandbox games, and worked extremely hard to avoid those problems. Jumping into the game, it's clear that this game doesn't intend to waste your time. The menus and overall feel are extremely smooth and quick. This seems to permeate the whole game's design; don't waste the player's time, let them do what they want, and look good doing it.

To start, most sandbox games take forever to mine a block. This one doesn't. And while the time it takes to mine a dirt or stone block decreases with better tech levels, it never feels  arduous to cut through a mountain or dig a tunnel. Which I think is fantastic in a game that's about digging tunnels. Your character occupies one block of space, and it takes under a second to mine one block.

After playing a bit, you get to the building" part
date: which is even simpler. The game dispenses with the idea of you manually putting down blocks of dirt that you picked up. Instead
recommended: you mix concrete and place *that*. It's one of about five basic block types you can place. While that seems limiting
hoursPlayed: it's actually freeing. I've never enjoyed making dirt palaces with haphazard streaks of cobblestone and sand. It lets you focus on the stuff you actually want to do; dig tunnels
voteText: get resources

and fight monsters.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dig or Die

Well, I died. But I'll dig again. In fact, I dig the digging in this game.
Dig Dug, was the first thing that came to my mind. Good old
Atari 2600 madness.

This was an impulse buy. And although it's just closing in to v.0.1,
I'm already having way too much fun. I played barely an hour,
and I'm gonna be just in time for an appointment, because
of lingering here, writing these lines and already have the
feeling, I got my money's worth.

The fighting is fun. It has a little Mega Man vibe, but without
the punishment. The crafting isn't getting tedious, so if you
like your crafting without the micro-management overkill
this might feel just right. But, I'm not too far in, although,
art direction, controls, environment, sound score, it all
sits right at the moment.

40 hours in, I'm still having a jolly good time. The community
that evolves around Dig or Die is also quiet friendly and helpful.
Not to a small part to the developer, who manages to be kind
and communicative at all times.

I especially like the approach to difficulty. Mastering the game
on normal, you'll find new challenges on brutal. Adapting your
approach. Enemies will only attack you at night, when you
provoked them in the day. So you can save, and have a
look how deep you want to get yourself in trouble.
While I thought myself master of the world on normal,
I was jumping around like a crazy ferret with a laser gun
on brutal. After some tries, then finally, the first survived
night on brutal. A victory, all the sweeter, for having learned
from previous mistakes, that never got tedious.

The game doesn't hate you. When you learned another trick,
you'll think to yourself, yeah sure, howcouldn't I have seen
that before? Cool beans! And now to the next adventure!

There's also an often updated devblog, that's always
worth a visit, at: http://gaddygames.tumblr.com/


March 2016 - Dig or Die has hit version 0.2

The graphics have gotten a complete overhaul.
Physics have been expanded. A.I. has gotten smarter.
Increased diversity in monsters, fauna and flora. I thought
it might have become too complex, but Dig or Die still
has its unique charme. Even though crafting isn't
really one the most regarded mechanics for me,
I find myself returning on this rainy planet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dig or die is still in early access and has just had the 0.1 update. Before that you could get off planet in the space of an in game week with ease ending the game. Now there are bosses to fight, more areas to explore with materials and things to craft from them and the promise of more to come. Patches at the moment are very frequent and tend to be not much more than a few kilobytes.

The game has an interesting way of pacing the difficulty which is explained by the ai computer in the wreckage beside you at the starting point. This happens in a couple of ways. One is that at night creatures become hostile and will be even more inclined to want to chew your face off than during the day. The other that some people might miss out on is that creatures only become hostile if you start killing them first. So if you run and gun during the first day there's a good chance that come nightfall death will follow.

You know those games about building a bridge on a tight budget where you end up making something from girders and knicker elastic? In some ways that is similar to how building works in dig or die. The higher you build the more stress blocks get and once they get too much things will collapse. So with the exceptions of floating islands having a skybase a la terraria isnt possible. Thankfully you can craft goggles that will show stresses when they're on the hotbar that make things a bit easier.

There's also rain, more than the average scottish summer, and that brings some changes as well. Digging requires a bit more thought as some tunneling habits will lead to death by drowning. The good news is that the water can be controlled and used for power or just flooding the world to save building up to the islands overhead.

Weaponary comes in handy for both killing stuff, obviously, as well as mobility. Rocket jumping isnt a new concept in video games, strangely enough the rocket launcher isnt the best for it in DoD, but a lot of the weapons have a knockback to them which means if you need a boost to cross a gap shooting down will give you the nudge needed. Sililarly if you're swimming in the ocean and start running out of air shooting down can get you to the surface faster.

Value wise, one playthrough from start to getting off planet should easily get you below the £1 per hour mark. Currently on around 30p per hour and falling so in the realms of witcher 3's levels of cost per hour.

And one last thing that I really like is that, unlike terraria, you aren't forced into looking at a wiki to find out what to do next. All the info you need to play is in the tooltips or mentioned by the crashed ai. It might not say specifically where to go for the black grass but it's easy enough to figure out black dirt is involved.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Gameplay
The actual gameplay is great for the first few nights, running around shooting creatures and trying not to die. When you get deeper into the game you start the base build part of the game (My fav part), you will need a brain for this or lots of real life experience with it.

The Graphics
The looks of the game are great for a one man team, not saying they are bad, but could use upgrading. I understand that the developer of the game is looking for a graphic artist during the making of this review so upgrades are on its way. (Update) New Graphics are now avaliable.

The Updates
The developer is putting his heart and soul into this game. With every update (As of this review the updates have been coming out once every 2-3 months) you can see the effort that the developer is putting into the game. The developer has also said that he plans to input multiplayer so if you want a game that is fun and will get better soon, this one would be a great investment.

The AI
The AI of the game is well balanced making the game fair on every level you play on it feels real (Peaceful feels peaceful, easy feels easy, normal feels normal, hard feels hard and so on).

The Realism
The realism of the games physics are fantastic. This feature really makes you need to think whenever you build, what do I need to get this done? How do I get this done? And will it work? This game is a real pain when something just does not want to work.

The Cons
There are not many cons to this game but just to balance the review here are some:
It’s made by only one person so updates take a while.
It’s not multiplayer (However this is coming soon)
The water in the game is a pain (This is part of what also makes it fun though)
And.... wow.... can't think of much else...


Should I Buy This?
In the end it’s up to you, but I do recommend this game. Hopefully this review has also helped you make up your mind on the matter of buying this game.

Rating
I don't quite know how much I should rate this game but I guess it would be something like 8 or so.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

BugZy's Review: Dig or Die - Almost as difficult as Super Meat Boy!

The following is my opinion.

Welcome to Dig or Die, the wonderful yet terribly hard 2D sandbox game where if you haven’t watched walkthroughs or read any helpful reviews, you’ll go through world after world before actually being half decent at the game. Trust me, this is far from your ordinary sandbox. Oh, and I would like to state that while being inspired by a game like Terraria, it is vastly different and a heck of a lot more difficult.

Here is a little background. Dig or Die is a game released in March 2015 by Gaddy Games. You are a representative for a space-based company called Craft & Co. and have crash landed on a hostile planet, leaving you stranded with no way to get out besides using the equipment manufactured by the company to survive and ultimately build a rocket ship to escape.

When you load up a new world, your gaming instincts will kick in and you will have the urge to kill every creature in sight, but let me warn you that if you do, it will make the game an astronomical amount harder than if you just mind your own business. Of course you will have to kill some things anyway for crafting materials and other stuff, but if you haven’t killed any of its kind and have no reason to, then try to resist the urge to obliterate it with your pulse rifle.

If you are wondering why I am warning you about this, it is because at night the enemies come as a wave of creatures trying to get their revenge. Basically, different types of creatures will attempt to kill you if you have killed said type of creature. For example if you kill a dog, more dogs will attack you. If you kill a giant blue wasp, waves of giant blue wasps will attack you, which leads to my next point.

Defense is a major part of Dig or Die, especially when - as I’ve stated above - the monsters attack in a big wave. You must build a fortified base that hopefully you can survive in by using turrets, sturdy walls and your nifty craft-o-tron to help build these. Be careful though, because the hostile creatures that your base so desperately defends you from can and will tear your base apart, so be prepared to repair things! Also keep an eye out for blocks that are holding up large amounts of other blocks as this game enforces the laws of physics and they, also, crumble apart.

Something I would like to point out is that there are quite frequent flash floods, which add a great deal to the game’s suspense and makes it even more difficult as your base can be flooded in a matter of seconds. This is another thing you should look out for, so just a tip: build drainage pipes!

The game works somewhat in tiers, where you start with MK I gear and try to go up through the ranks to get better equipment, to venture further and get more items to craft better stuff and survive for longer. Eventually, you will have climbed the ladder of better items and will be able to create the rocket ship that I mentioned earlier, which is where the game ends.

The game’s art style is incredibly beautiful, being what you would imagine from a cartoon-styled game set in an alien planet. The animations can seem jittery and not-so-smooth, but if you are not paying lots of attention to them there isn’t really much of a problem.

The music and sound effects feel very fitting to the game’s atmosphere. I have had a few encounters where the music stops altogether when a sound effect plays and doesn’t start again until another sound effect plays, usually when I shoot my pulse rifle, but that is only a very small issue that I have come across and haven’t seen anyone else complain about it, so it could just be for me.

In conclusion, Dig or Die is a brilliant game. There may be some issues here and there, but in the end the game is a great play and for the price it is, I wouldn’t think twice about recommending it to any friend who enjoys 2D sandboxes.

I rate Dig or Die 8.5/10 hungry dingos.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:
~It's not another sandbox survival/horror dayz/Rust/etc.
~Pretty neat physics(Guns propel you backwards with recoil, water runs downhill)
~Turrets
~Runs smoothly
~Small download size(Aprox. 77 mb)
~Fairly smooth controls
~Fun
~Drill/pick/saw all combined into one easy tool right off the bat
~DOOM difficulty-tier settings
~2.99$ and you've bought the whole game, for life
(Now 4.99, still a good deal)
As of the most current update, the water has been toned down, it no longer pours for half a day, but showers occassionally.  Building is still a case of fake it till you make it, but it's easier with experimenting.

Cons:
~Went a little overboard with the water(mitigated with most recent update)
~Not much weather variety
~No character customization as of yet
~No multiplayer
~Also it doesn't lack in content, but it could do with more.

It costs less than some coffees from Starbucks, and it'll last longer. With Steam's new refund feature there's no reason not to try this out.  Two hours of time is a decent amount to decide if you like it or not. If it's not your cup of tea, then ok.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-OUT OF DATE--OUT OF DATE--OUT OF DATE--OUT OF DATE--OUT OF DATE--OUT OF DATE--
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

So where do I start wth this game?

I guess with a bunch of curt statements about the pros and cons, before I get on to the full review.

Pros:
-Varying tiers of difficulty.
-Difficulty curve that you control. (mostly)
-Challenging building physics.
-Decent amount of content for $3 (With price slowly being raised as game is developed)
-Not some cheap money-grab knock-off of terraria or anything like that.
-Night is somewhat short (Only played Easy, so I don't know if it gets longer at higher difficulties)
-It has an ending (You escape), but you can avoid it.
-Enemy AI is relentless. And I mean it.
-Rain physics.

Cons:
-Enemies WILL overwhelm you on playthrough one.
-Building physics take getting used to.
-Released like a week ago, so may be unbalanced/not enough content at the moment.
-Indie (Lower funding/Less employees than triple A studios, so dev time may be longer)
-It has an ending within only a few hours (Will probaby get longer as development goes on).
-Night starts to feel much more pathetic, and the shortness of it gets annoying, once you get high tier items. I often find myself wishing for a gamemode with a 15-20 minute setup, then an infinite night. Or at least customizeable timers.
-Rain. Physics.

Basically, this game is Terraria mixed with Xenominer mixed with **some game that requires you to escape a planet** (Shut up, I couldn't think of anything)

So let's start with my first playthrough.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NOTE: This CAN, and WILL, spoil your first playthrough. STOP READING NOW if you have already decided to purchase it. Trust me, the first playthrough is so much more fun blind.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

(Note 2: I'm refraining from mentioning any part of rain or water in my playthroughs, because it's basically everywhere, all the time. No need to tell you that it rains every minute. It hardly affected me this early into the game.)

I immediately charged to the far right side, thinking like a terrarian, trying to explore everything. Within seconds I encountered yellow flying bugs and yellow dogs. No big deal, super weak, killed them with ease. Went farther, and after about a minute, I found a black colored variant of the flying enemies. It took ages to kill with the starter weapon. Unfortunately, here's where I had issues. I read nothing in the quick help menu, and only listened to the AI for a short while. So when I decided to bunker down for the night, I didn't realise what I had brought upon myself.

Context: The game's difficulty curve is technically one that you control. You will only get assaulted at night by enemies that you killed during the day.

I didn't know that.

Within seconds there was an absolute HORDE of the black flying enemies. I had only a few concrete walls (which stood no chance) and one weak turret (RIP) in between me and unescapeable death. It was over in 20 seconds. I had no chance. Luckily, I had thought to quicksave... after I had killed the black flying enemy.

So on to my second playthrough. I learned pretty fast. Only killed the yellow flying enemy and yellow dogs for the first few nights while I built up. Then the AI clued me into some flowers to the west to get my T3 autocrafter. So I immediately went east, like the smart man that I am.

To the west: Red flying enemies, the next step up from the yellow ones. Not easy, but not difficut either.

I made a mistake.

I went east and found the black ones again. Figured me, my 12 turrets, and my 3-thick concrete walls could take take them.

I was wrong. Again.

I lasted nearly until morning that time. But by halfway through the night there were droves of them. It felt like a bombing run. I was down to 3 turrets which I had hastily evacuated to my basement. They were busy with all manner of dogs that I killed during the day (Higher tiers than the yellow, but dogs don't hurt nearly as much as the flying enemies), which left me valiantly defending against the fliers.

It went well for about 3 minutes. Then the dogs broke through the turrets.

With just me and my getling gun left in that hole-filled basement, I went down again.

And I made the mistake of autosaving just before nightfall again. 2 more attempts got me no closer to daytime.

I've yet to start a third playthrough. I'm trying to plan my house on paper beforehand this time, decide choke points, where the walls should be thicker, thinner, supported, where to place turrets, where to place lights, where to place myself, and all other things I can think of. But I can say without a doubt that this game is challenging.

And I'm only on Easy. There's still 4 higher difficulty levels.

Time to get crackin'.

Dig or Die... its all in the name.

I've play a lot of sandbox games but this one finds a special place in my heart of gaming!

Like most I've played all the mainstream sandbox games and when i found this little gem i knew i had to try it. Remember being stuck outside with no base to speak of in Minectraft, Terraria and the like? the next day after hopefully not dying over and over again you build a base then..... nothing. Terraria added some nifty features with zombies knocking on doors and breaking them down and Minecraft has mods but none that feel like this game.

Never mind the awesome physics or the quick and easy crafting system it was the base defense and path-finding mobs that made me fall for this game. I've been a fan of the tower defense genre as well as sandbox games and too see them together, but more importantly, to see them put together well, I was amazed. Remember your first night in Dig or Die?

I had diggin into the side of the hill my spaceship had landed on. i dug in deep with my 2 turrets and shotgun which i had the the luck of killing enough fireflys to craft and enough scrap for iron. i had watched some videos so i knew what to expect. leaving a hole for the mobs to come in i felt safe..... i was wrong. they came from below and both sides, within moments i was running, screaming like a little girl trying to dig deeper to avoid the continuous stream on monsters trying to devour me. Its safe to assume i didn't make it and i will now admit that was my 3rd first night.

Play this game and you'll like it!

Also i would like to note the replay ability of this game, its a sandbox so each time try something different and learn something new. My hat is off to the developer, you sir have made my day and many more to come.

My input for the game would only be a harder survival mode. Not just stronger mobs, but make them dig, walk, shoot, strike better based off of how many in day games you've been around. Once you've built the best base you can where everything repairs and lasts the night what then.... sure you can leave the planet but what if you want to stay!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A good shorter game (by crafting game standards) of about 12-15 hours.

Dig or Die is fairly reminiscent of Terraria, having several similarities, but differentiates itself on it's more modern focus.
Whereas Terraria would be all about the bosses, RNG weapon/item drops from monsters and fantasy, and Starbound is about the exploration of strange new worlds and upgrading your spaceship, Dig or Die is a shorter more personal story about survival and escape from a hostile planet.

You are accompanied by your ship's AI that, like the Guide in Terraria, gives you advice and hints on what to do next. You're free to do whatever you want, however, as the enemy progression in the game is cleverly tied into the exploration.
Every night you're assaulted by rabid creatures that want to rid the planet of your presence, but the only ones that attack you are species you've already killed a member of.
The bases you build are basically just forts with one singular purpose: to keep you alive at night, There're a myriad of traps and turrets available to choose from, and each is useful in its own way. As you advance up the tech tree, more toys become available to help protect you against the new & nastier enemies you've angered to get there.

Finally, I'll talk a bit about the water physics.
The water is this game is the best implementation of it I've seen in any crafting game ever. While it's a bit overexaggerated in it's flow and abundance, it otherwise behaves just as you expect water should.
The game simulates pressure, flow and absorbtion to a very impressive degree. Massive rainfalls ensure you always have to contend with it, or have your bases and mines flooded. Dirt will absorb water into it, which is released underneath it or when broken. Mining underwater is a hazard due to the inability of crafting air pockets, as the water pressure pushes the surface upwards.
You can also harness the water for use with hydroelectric dams and pumps, and managing the flow of water to your advantage is a constant concern.

Physics is also applied to forced acting on the blocks you place.
While underground this is a non-issue, as the blocks are always supported by the background layer, but above ground (and other places where there's no background layer) you have to consider thw weight and resistance of the blocks you place, or the whole construction will come crashing down.
I kinda wish it'd simulate the different kinds of material stresses better, as even concrete cannot stand vertical towers for very high before it just bursts, but at least it provides an engineering challenge.

So:
In summary, Dig or Die is a fun little crafting game focusing on survival and tower defense elements in a (partially) physics driven hostile world.
I had fun with it, and for the pricetag you could certainly do a lot worse.
It's a charming little game, with some cool engineering puzzles to solve and fun combat.
Oh, and the battle music kicks ♥♥♥ ;)

reviewText:

Rock eating dogs, biblical flooding, mass deforestation and a rewriting of the laws of physics For every action there's a ten times more powerful and opposite reaction" are just some of the wonders of this alien planet in Dig or Die.

Granted
date: it's only been pre-released for a week so much of this will undoubtedly change
hoursPlayed: make the game a bit more enjoyable than most of it's counterparts on the market.\n\nAt its current state
voteText:
it's a short(ish) game. You essentially have 3 "levels" to get through. Each level is dependent on how far you upgrade a core piece of equipment (similar to a workbench in other games). And then there are the enemy levels which scale according to how far you explore; spend your first day going as far across the map as possible and you will die horribly come night.

That's one of the ways this game sets itself apart from some of the others like it. There is a serious and real threat to you. It takes a page out of 7 Days to Die's playbook and throws a real challenge at you when night comes. Every enemy you've encountered swarms around you or your base come nightfall. Gives you a real reason to set up some good defenses!

And these aren't mindless zombie drones we're talking about. Even though their options are limited
helpfulPercent: the enemies will use whatever means at their disposal to get to you... directly to you
votesHelpful:
even if it means tearing down 12 feet of concrete block.

Physics (to a degree) are another factor that make it different. I'd also compare this to 7 Days to Die in that each material has a different strength to support other blocks; build up too high or out too far and your walls will crumble over.

The third and last

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the end of the day, I wasn't as moved as everybody else by Terraria, even though I was psyched and did pick it up on day one. Dig or Die is a much more 'conservative' take on a Terraria-esque game; most importantly to me, it has an endgame goal that is presented to you at the begining, and a cohesive art/ambient theme. No clowns and laser guns mixed with battle-axes here. The artwork is very nice, as well - less pixel art this time. It feels much more reserved, than 'in-your-face' considering its pastel colors and mellow music.

Essentially, you crash land on a planet, and need to gather the resources to both protect yourself as well as get off the planet. It has various difficulty levels, but proves challenging at even 'easy'. Its really easy on the eyes and things all make fairly logical sense. The menus are intuitive enough. There is also some mild tower defense elements that are quite welcome.

Most of all, the price is right - five bucks is too low, in fact, for the content you are given.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There's nothing wrong with a game taking heavy inspiration from a popular title if said game does enough to differentiate itself from the title it is taking inspiration from. Dig Or Die differentiates itself from Terraria by taking the Terraria formula and emphasizing tower defense and construction elements while significantly compacting the experience.

In Dig Or Die, you play a man who has crashed on an alien planet and must build a rocket ship to escape. You do this by collecting resources and gradually climbing up the tiers of a crafting system until you can build a rocketship and leave the planet. You'll have to survive until then and when nighttime comes that's when the party arrives. Nights in Dig Or Die are short but brutal. The player is swarmed by monsters and the best course of action is to build a base with several turrets because even if you have state-of-the-art firearms it won't be easy taking out the enemies by yourself.

Tower defense is a large part of Dig Or Die. The main challenge throughout the game will be surviving the nights as increasingly difficult enemies attack you during nightfall. The game allows you to control how quickly the game's night assault difficulty increases by only adding in a type of enemy into the night defense roster after you've killed it during the daytime in its natural habitat. Turret construction will also come in use when you are fighting bosses because chances are your weapons won't be killing them quick enough.

The other big gimmick with Dig Or Die is the construction physics. Anything that's not built in front of a natural background wall will have to abide to the game's complex physics systems. You cannot just simply build a pillar of blocks to the sky, no. The player will have to build eventually because some biomes (and therefore, some crucial resources) are trapped away beyond neverending chasms and the like. It's a very satisfying puzzle, building these constructions and this reviewer enjoyed it a lot even though sometimes it was hard to understand how weight distribution worked.

One thing that doesn't get mentioned enough is how Dig Or Die plays with spectacle. Finding new biomes and new enemies is very thrilling and its pretty surprising how deep you can dig down into the earth. Your journey will take you to some very exciting places and there are all sorts of surprises to uncover, at a pacing that sets it ahead of Terraria.

In conclusion, those looking for a briefer and quicker Terraria-like experience with heavy defense elements and a construction system that provides interesting puzzles should give Dig Or Die a purchase.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game starts off simple. You are stranded, shipwrecked on a foreign planet. You have some tools to use at your disposal and some scrap materials from your shipwreck. Along with your ship's AI, you develop a plan to scavenge to try and discover a method to get off this wretched planet. But like all epic tales, what begins as simple quickly turns to a battle between life or death. If you were a fan of Terraria, Edge of Space, Starbound and similar gathering and crafting 2d survival games, this is certainly up your alley. But this time, you will have to Dig or Die.

Do you have what it takes? This game succeeds in differentiating itself from the rest, and had me on the edge of my seat at many moments. I suggest you pick up this title and find out.  Two thumbs up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I picked up the game  as beta v0.06, not really expecting much, and it delivered.

But then v0.10 came out and sweet holy mercy! Well, it changed a lot and the game got a lot bigger with a lot more to do.  The number of hours I have put into playing the game should say something about how much I enjoy playing it. Hours will slip by and I will wonder where the day went.

About the game.

You have crashed on a planet and you must survive the night creatures. And only the creature types you have killed will hunt you at night. So start digging up necessary ore's or your going to die!

The water physics in the game were a challenge at first, but it really makes the game unique and fun. Use the water to your advantage with hydroelectric generators to power equipment. Craft solar cells to collect energy during the day. Create a base with turrets to protect yourself at night. Its all there, waiting for you to find it, to collect it, to bring it home and to build with it.

You must battle (at the moment, two) bosses in order to collect special items so you can build unique equipment to help you in your quest to escape the planet. The final mission is to build a rocket ship so you can finally leave this hostile planet.

All in all, I find the game adictive. If your not into 2D platform style games, then this may not be for you. But if you enjoy exploring, building and battling, and you can look beyond the game style, your going to love this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game promises to be fantastic!

The Early Access is a complete -- but shorter -- game of the final version that is very replayble, fun and addictive. It's well worth the low cost that's asked and the bonus of getting the final version for free is even better. Dig or Die has a great balance between grind/craft/build that doesn't become tedious like other games. Just when you think it will, you progress and unlock new things that change what you need to do. There's no going back and grinding out level 1 resources; you've always got enough just by playing and exploring. The progression feels natural, not laborious, and doesn't wear you down.

By far the best part of this game is the base defence. The combination of mining/crafting with tower-defence/building is amazing. Coupled with the under-spoken sci-fi theme it's a real joy to play. Highly recommended. Can't wait for the final version.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A beautiful gem in the making

Dig or Die is already an engaging experience. A reminder of the time when
games had vision. It is also a demonstration for the beauty of 2d and that
perspective is not a limitation of time and technology, but a decision -
for art-style and direction. Dig or Die is many pieces that manage to
come together and form an harmonic whole.

Watching its process is like watching an artist painting a canvas.
There's already a picture in the mind, the only thing is waiting
for the process for it to manifest for it into reality.

And this canvas is already an enjoyable outlook of things to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is really fun. Though, I think Dig or Die isn't most fitting title for this game... Neverless....
This game is very well made for the start of early access.  Water, Water, Water.... every where.  Yes. There is tons of water but if your smart enough, you build your base on the highest part of the Mountain. If the monsters are too high of a level, build to the start of the area where the monsters are high level.
So it begins, for new players: Normal is more on 'learning the game mode of survival' and Hard is well... Hard.

When I started this game, I did it on  Hard  and I suffered painfully. After 3 deaths from Hard difficulty night time, I decided it was best to start a normal game. I kept on forgetting to save the game, because if you don't save it... You have to start all over again if you die.  Water wasn't a problem for me on Normal [after 3 games], because I connected the water waste to the huge tunnels that goes wayyyyy below.  -The most important part of this game is:
-180* turrets on top of the roof
some 180* turrets on the bottom with straight turrets going inward where the house is.
This way, none of the monsters can destroy your house.
Make sure your house is off the ground by 4-5 blocks high so that the monsters can't jump up.
-The other thing is, I strongly recommend having cement blocks and wood platform 1by1
This will help you shoot below, jump up to your house, filter the rain out of your house if it manage to get through, and let the excess Wasp monster to come through the bottom if the turrets can't kill them fast enough. Make sure you have a lot of health potions.

Overall, I love the game for what it is right now. But you may be like-  there some negative reviews!"
There is only one thing I got to say about that:
"Wahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh. Noah Ark Simulator. Wahhhhhhhhh."
- Get over it. Build tunnels into caves. Build your house on the mountain. Be a man.

Good Job for making this game. I'm glad that I bought tons of this game gifts now than later."

Alright, so first off-- this game is pretty freaking great.

Pros: Being able to save progress as you go, (love me some save states), nice difficulty to it, great physics logic, enemies can even break your ♥♥♥♥. (try to build a base, I dare you.)

Cons:  Upgrading tools-- You have to keep the one you upgrade in order craft certain items (it's basically teir specific), you can't just have one upgraded crafting thing, you have to have multiple if you want to backtrack.  It'd be more convenient in case you lose the smaller one. (Trust me, I've lost an upgrade before, it'd be pretty balls to lose the first one you get.), So much water. maybe a way to drain it or something?

Overview:  Although I enjoy the game, it's best to grab it while it's still in development before the price goes up.  You probably won't regret it if you enjoy this type of game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For my full review and other delicious content see Glitch

Developed and published by Gaddy Games, a small indie studio that has dabbled in both the gaming and advergame markets, Dig or Die is a 2D, sandbox, strategy/adventure game currently in early access. You are a galactic salesperson, selling automated fabrication tools. On a recent trip your ship crash lands on a strange planet, full of hostile creatures. You must put your fabrication tools to good use, and gather the local resources to build the structures and weapons needed to explore this new world and survive the nights.

The game kicks off with the protagonist outside their crashed ship, and leaves the player too start exploring and gathering resources. The crashed ship's AI offers some timely advice about some of the native creatures and some ideas on how to survive. Using your Miniaturizor you can mine the basic items of the world, and by killing different enemies collect valuable resources to build defences, and upgrade weapons and your autobuilder.

I like this minimal instruction, as it is great fun getting in over your head in the early game. As you learn more about the world and find different resources, you will build stronger walls and the more powerful weapons and turrets needed to survive the onslaught of creatures each night. The night onslaughts are great fun, and have a tower defence feel.

As you progress the game starts to get a good rhythm , of exploring for new resources, then collecting all you can, before choosing a defensive location and digging in for the night. After surviving the night, I found it best to pack up my modest camp and move on in search of more resources. The resource gathering is well paced, and the requirement to upgrade your autobuilder repeatedly, to get to the best building materials, weapons and Miniaturizor is a great motivator to take risks when exploring.

Overall, I was quickly drawn in and addicted to the rhythm and exploration in Dig or Die. I found the pacing to be spot on, with each day cycle giving you just enough time to increase your overall resource pool, before fighting out the night. The upgrade system with the autobuilder, dangles the carrot perfectly and had me searching every inch of this world for weird and wonderful resources. I can't wait to see what other craftable items become available throughout this games development, and recommend this game to anyone who enjoys sandbox creation and exploration.

Pros Beautiful, large scale water simulation
Building physics that balance difficulty and accessibility
Night defense system, only monsters you kill in the day attack at night

Nonrenewable resources
No multiplayer (yet!)

Basically, get this game. Now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of fun right now. Very short learning curve...if you've played Terraria or any of the others in this genre, you can pick it up right away. The only thing that threw me at first was that you have to create multiple work stations that appear identical, but learning is learning. :)

The water physics in this are spot on. Very smooth. The nights are short, frantic and fun, and you breathe a sigh of relief when daylight comes! I only played on easy just to get to grips with the game, but I can see this being a massive time sink for me.

The stage the game is at right now is very playable, and if you like Terraria mashed up with a little bit of 7 Days to Die, you can't go wrong here for this price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game when it first came out, to see the differences between this and Terraria as I was a big fan of it. At first I didn't expect much from a new Early Access game which only costed RM8 (Malaysian Ringgit), but I was BLOWN AWAY by the mechanics of Dig or Die !

Story & ObjectiveYou crash landed on an unknown hostile planet because you're a horrible pilot, you had no choice but to survive horrible nights and collect materials to build another rocket to fly home.

CombatsHardcore and fun. Combats are fast-paced so you had to have good aim of the enemy while running and jumping around the place to avoid enemy attacks.

ChallengesThere are many challenges I like about this game, one I came across is building a bridge to cross the huge gap to get precious materials. Building a bridge is not as easy as I thought it would be, the game has AMAZING physics implemented, the blocks break when it cannot support the amount of weight, falling to death several times is common.

GraphicsWhen it first came out, the graphics weren't as good as the graphics it has now, the developer hired a professional artist through community voting for the best suitable new graphics for the game. Dig or Die has very colorful graphics, literally candy to the eyes.

DeveloperThe developer is very active, and actually adds things to the game unlike most Early Access devs. He also responds to nearly every single thread in the forums and accepts ideas from the community.

Overall Score
9.367/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to punctuate this review with one sentence because it's what kept me satisfied through my first few hours of play; You can use the recoil from a shotgun to jump higher and use this to one shot enemies that were previously out of range.

The fluid mechanics are pretty good, even there's enough water to contend with a flooded Venice. Then again, you can clear the bridge" challenge by using the recoil from the shotgun.

The enemies are nicely varied if a bit overpowered by being able to dig and swim infinitely (even the flying ones). If there was an achievment for killing 6 enemies while airborn
recommended: thanks to the shotgun.\n\nThe night combat gets inane and tedious once you've realised you can build a huge base in the minded out "crater" of a mountain. There really should be multiplayer so I can blast my friends with my shotgun
hoursPlayed: while flying over them in a hail of shot and glory.\n\nThis game has a huge amount of potential but needs a significant amount of development and balancing. Shotgun is love

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DIG or DIE is a survival/mining open world sandbox game.
In it you must explore, dig, kill monsters, and of course, survive.
Like most in it's genre there is a day/night cycle.
You must be ready to face them or hide from them by night.
However in THIS game there is no hiding. (At least on night one.)
There will be plenty of monsters on your ♥♥♥ and it will be DARK!
Im talking about silhouette dark. So save at sunset.
If you don't have a save to load then you lose your world, simple as that.
Apparently if you don't bother or kill mobs they won't hurt you at night.
The problem is that they attack you during the day. Kinda making that a moot point.
Crafting is easy to use. There's a bit too much of the whole I need this item I don't know how to find to progress.
This game has awesome music. Calm for the midday labors and tense for the night fight or flight.
I wish there were more though. There are no sounds for digging and collecting which is sad. As far as I know there is only one biome. The plains/hills. The game looks good in my opinion. I like the way it looks.
The combat feels weird and sorta stiff. I can't explain it but it isn't a snoothe as say
date:
Spelunkey or Minecraft.
As for the mobs themselves they are aggravating at best. You have a flying creature a dog and a mole creature. And they are tiny!
They are hard to aim at. My biggest gripe is that their shots break blocks. NO! One mob is fine but ALL of them is a bad idea.
The biggest problem im currently having is the god damn flooding! It's happening all the time. At random! Anytime it rains your home is flooded. It seems as if there are no other weather effects so they put in rain to fill times where future planned weather
effects would be. The options are limited at best. https://twitter.com/SnowWither/status/574784805264474112
Overall a good title that should get better over time. It's early access and it will raise in price with updates. Get it.
Pros:                      score
Great music                 +1
Cool&dangerous night        +1
Good looking game           +1?
Good Crafting GUI           +2

Cons:
No digging/collecting snds -1
Weird combat               -1
Flooding                   -2
Mobs destroy blocks        -2


(? means you and keep or remove it based on your opinion.)
Score: -1 Score w/o ?: -2

It's 3$ or your regional equivalent. Get it now. Despite my score
recommended: get it when it is cheap. My complaints will most likely be fixed in the next update.  Thanks for reading."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome game. Keeps the simplicity of the Tower Defense, but also adds a bit of terraria/minecraft/starbound feel to it.

PROS:
- Oldies graphics
- Relaxing music during day, exasperating during night.
- Nice variety of manual weapons
- Challenge to build actual structures in a 2d game (Most of them just lets you place anything anywhere)
- Very challenging once you've ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off all the mobs.
- Nice GUI
- The requirements to progress forces you to go all over the map,

CONS:
- From time to time it seems like the mob swarms are a bit overpowered.
- The map is limited.
- It's hard to understand how the physics of the buildings works. (You end up placing ♥♥♥♥ everywhere and pray to god it will hold that way)
- There are not enough turrets in stock.

Saying all that, I must say its a super good game, due it's alpha state. What I think it should be added:

- More materials, weapons and items.
- More mobs
- More stages or steps you have to get through to get the ♥♥♥♥ out the planet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game about digging and how it will inevitably lead to death by exploding mosquitoes, fire breathing mosquitoes, plasma shooting mosquitoes, or some other form of mosquito equipped with logistically unlikely projectiles.

The game is won by successfully drowning yourself without being hit by mosquitoes.  Other obstacles you will face are uppity regenerating pro-life fish, bending water (that is presumably being bribed by the fish to obstruct your quest), and floating cactuses that will fall out of the sky because they are depressed or their home sports team did not win the championship.

Before you can properly drown yourself, you will need to scrounge for materials and develop technology in order to build a basin large enough to hold the necessary water without exploding because gravity, and equip it with automated defenses to keep away both the fish and the mosquitoes, as well as put the water in its place, should it decide to tilt or twist in an unhelpful manner.

Finally, you will need to build a rocket ship and program it to launch your carcass into space, because if you can't have a space funeral then what is the point?  Turning on the rocket will summon large quantities of protesting fish, mosquitoes, and angry water that your defenses will have to deal with on their own because at this point you will already be dead, so this requires some planning and engineering skills, and for me was one of the more enjoyable aspects of the game.

The rocket blueprint is questionable and probably was stolen from someone's 8th grade science project and sold on Craigslist, as the primary material needed to make it is the still-beating heart of an immortal space rock that floats in the atmosphere and probably was important to maintaining the planet's ecosystem, as killing it causes it to fall out of the sky, followed by a lot of rain, frogs, earthquakes, locusts, volcanic eruptions, plague, and a sudden disparity in the ratio of pro-life fish to their more aggressive eastern European cereal mascot shark counterparts, but what's important is that you get your awesome space funeral.  Good luck, soldier.

If you're balancing on whether to buy this game or not, you should because it will only get better from here. I hope multplayer comes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Addicting Gameplay, Smooth Mechanics, Pleasing Art Style
Only with a few hours of gamplay (I plan on playing a lot more), I can say that Dig or Die is a well-done piece of work. Only being an Early Access title, the game has already impressed and entertained me more than I expected. The mechanics are solid, I have not run into any buggy gameplay, etc. The concept is intriguing and not overly complicated. It also has a reasonably difficult playstyle, with enough fun per difficulty. The gameplay is just smooth, and it definitely doesn't waste time with unnecessary lag or long loading screens; in other words, the game is already showing a fine polish. I love playing the game, I would highly recommend it before it goes full price, because this game has a lot of potential! It already is a blast to play, and I can't wait for what else the developer brings to the table.

So, overall a Good game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For 4,99€ you just can't go wrong, even for 12€ (the final price), it's a must buy in it's current state.

Why? Game play is polished and addictive, in my 46 (so far) hours of game play I have not ran into single bug, the learning curve is just right, it's extremely easy to get into but not so easy to master. Kinda like math, it's easy when you just have numbers but add the alphabet and it gets complicated.

Most extraordinary of it all are the water physics, I have never seen such great physics in any game, be it a 60€ title or something I bought for 0.99€. The water just flows so naturally coupled with a soothing background music it creates such an serene atmosphere. At times I just stood in my base, listened to nearby waterfalls and music.

But don't take this for a serenity simulator, it's far from that. The game day is divided into day and night, day is the building and gathering phase and night is the survival phase. The nights can get quite tense, especially when you discover never and stronger enemies. Ramp up the difficulty and it's a real challenge to survive.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just got this game for it's $2.99 pricetag and oh my god is that the biggest deal I have ever seen.

I only have 40 minutes in this game so far (At least at the time of this review) and I am already having a blast scavenging for supplies and building a defensive system before night falls and I get swarmed by the hostile wildlife in the unknown planet our protagonist lands in.

In this game, Dig or Die, the story is basically that your character was part of some company, and your ship crash lands in this unknown world. Almost instantly, you are thrust into gameplay, with a little funny AI companion to guide you along your way. A few seconds in, and he tells you that you must look for supplies to make turrets before night comes, and you are forced to fight for your life. I got supplies and even got some wood with this cool little gizmo thing that's supposed to act as your 'mining' mechanic. It kind of reminds me of the gravity gun from the Half Life series, in it's look. I built a small fort with 2 sentries mounted on each side and hoped for the best went night came, and my god, was that one of the most epic fights I have ever had.

While the music in the day time is peaceful and serene, when the monsters are unleashed after dawn, it turns into some epic, badass soundtrack that just made me feel awesome while I shot monsters left and right, determined to keep them away from my base, determined to keep myself safe.

When night makes way to light, I have to work hard to find upgrades to my supplies, get better armor and better weapons as while you progress, the game gets increasingly difficult. But it all depends on how hard you chose your game to be in the settings. This is only the surface of the game, I've scratched, in almost just 1 hour of gameplay. The only issue I currently have with the game is that when the rain comes, it rains for only a few seconds, and it completely floods the land. Not a lot, but just enough to bug me and other players as it seems. I hope this gets fixed. Other than that, this game is completely worth it's price and people should get it. I can't wait for the full release!

9.5/10. I approve. Awesome game so far!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll put it simply: If you are thinking about getting this game, get it. If you aren't thinking about getting this game, get it anyway. This game combines traditional 2D sandbox mechanics with build-a-base mechanics. The concept is simple: Collect resources as best you can during the day, and fight off hordes of monsters during the night. However, this game makes you think. This game makes you consider every path, every defence, every resource, every kill, and every risk on every step of the way.

Another thing that separates it from the rest are the mechanics. What other game makes you consider  water pressure  in your defence strategy? Suffice it to say, you won't find any floating blocks in this game!

Now of course, comes the cons. The complaints I have in this game are few. For one thing, it rains too much. You may complain about Minecraft rain being too loud, but in this game flooding is a serious problem. It can mess with your movement (which can easily kill you in more tense situations) and given enough time can break your structures. Another problem would be the building is a little... off. Just little things, like a block breaking when it shouldn't have or the support behaving unexpectedly, but they could still use some fine tuning.

When it comes right down too it, that's all that's wrong with this game; it just needs some fine tuning. As a game that still in it's early stages, all it's problems should be taken with a grain of salt. From the time you're climbing the steep learning curve to when you've conquered its challenges, the game remains fun the whole time.

Over all, a fun game with huge potential, and one I would happily pay three times as much for.

Honestly, for £1.99 this game is Amazing.

*Challenging
*Proper strategy required
*Good difficulty curve (though I died on the first night 5 times before I got the hang of it)
*Effective day night system which keep things interesting / add pressure when carrying out repair / exploring
*Pretty smart physics system with collapsible structures, decent fluid mechanic (rain fills lakes, water pressure etc.)
*Has an absolutely AMAZING experience early on when you are exploring the planet that you can only really experience once.  It changes your whole perspective of the game.

I would GLADLY pay £20 for this game.

Love it. I like the day and night cycle and that it'll show how long you will have until day is over. I like how the mobs will only attack you at night if #1 you're close to them or #2 you attacked one of that particular species at some point already. I also like the different difficulty settings. One thing I would change if I could is not to have as many mobs starting out, because when I'm looking for a place to build after my first move I don't want to be running down too many mobs and end up getting swarmed by them all at night. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, I absolutely recomend this game if you like Terraria.  I haven't been playing terribly long at the point I'm writing this review, just about 4 hours.  The thing is, that's 4 hours in the same day... Which is huge for me with what is currently a single player game. So far, I have but one complaint, and that is: No co-op mode.  I have no idea if they plan to add one, and it's already loads of fun, but I'd absolutly love to play this with friends and familly. As the game is still in development, that could change.

That said: I like this game BETTER than Terraria, it just made more sense to me on an intuitive level. I've been learning very  quickly.

You set your own difficulty at the start, but also in the game as you progress. You do get mobbed at night, but only by the creatures you've killed before, so if you aren't in a really defensible location, just don't kill anything new.  The game makes it hard to get too far too fast. This is good, as the farther you are from the start, the harder the foe.

Seriously, for a game this early in dev, at the price point its at... Dig or Die is way more fun than I was expecting.  I've heard the price is going to rise with the updates, so I recomend getting it now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game. Hardcore, permadeath, realistic survival.

It lets you go at your own pace, which by my standards is not the best feature, since a player can get stuck unintentionally from going out and getting new things. but for more casual players, this feature is totally fine.

The enemies are unique for each and every one of them, and the deeper you go, the more enemies you find. you also find more resources, to craft better gear, and to make better weapons. the movement is smooth, the controls spot on, and the combat fluid.

If you like survival 2d games like terraria, then try this game. If you like roguelike 2d games like risk of rain, than try this game out. it has random generation, expansive world, crafting, shooting, building, and REALISTIC WATER PHYSICS!!!!

to be honest, this game is a gem that is worth way more than 5 bucks. I imagine that I could get at least 3 times the playtime that I already have on this game, just because it is so much addicting fun. multiple save files are nice too, meaning that you can have one world fully geared out and then start a new run on the hardest difficulty and see how far you get.

BUY. THIS. GAME. Understand?


Also, the title should be dig and die, because most deaths come from underground. If you don't dig, you can sit in you perfect night survival setup like a little B*tch and live forever. But don't do that. That's stupid and uninteresting. Go out and explore, and then get buttraped by incredibly powerful enemies!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dig or Die is a nice touch to the 2D sandbox genre. It easily combines Tower Defense elements with physics and a strong sense of survival. Graphics have some time getting used to, but blends together nicely. The only issues I found was the questionable save system and the structural physics. For someone who prefers casual games with a mix of hardcore elements, the structures in this game require knowledge of basic construction and more often than not hinders half of the creativity games like this want to become. If you don't know what I'm talking about, all of your buildings and creations must follow physical properties and be well supported, along with being not too heavy. I understand the appeal, but It doesnt suit a sandbox game in my opinion. Lastly the save system needs to be completely revamped. Currently your game auto-saves after every night but can be manually saved at any time. If your character dies, its gone forever until you reload a previous save. This means you lose everything you obtain between saves and amplifies the feeling of dread when a simple respawn system would fix this.

I understand the game is not complete. If you enjoy a sanbox game with a slice of realism go for it. Until multiplayer is added, I do not see this game even coming close to the behemoths of Terraria and Starbound. Overall, A good game, with niche mechanics.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dig or Die is an exellent mash-up of tower defense and 2D mine-crafting. It reminds me very favorably of Terraria 1.0 but with its own unique twist. You start off marooned on an unfriendly planet after crashing your spaceship with nothing but an all-purpose mining tool and a crafting station. To survive you'll need to quickly gather all the materials to build a base capable of holding off the hordes of enemies that will swarm you at night. Gameplay is simple but functional; you mine and harvest materials and enemies to upgrade your Miniaturizer and Auto-Crafter so you can build bigger and better guns to kill bigger enemies with. Eventually you'll gain access to the materials needed to build a rocket and escape the planet.

Now, after reading several reviews that warned of the game's difficulty, I decided to start my first game on normal, which turned out to be fairly easy. The fact that new, stronger enemies only attack at night once you've killed one of their type coupled with my tendency to overprepare meant that I never died at night and rarely died at all unless I overextended myself. My second playthrough was on brutal, which was an entirely different ballgame. The combination of increased enemy health and decreased player health meant that my first night was only beaten through luck and many reloads. It was still fairly easy once I farmed enough turrets, but there were some massive difficulty spikes on nights when I had killed a particularly tough enemy (like red or explosive fireflies) to upgrade my Miniaturizer but couldn't gather enough of the newly available resources to build stronger turrets.

Perhaps the biggest difference between Dig or Die and other block simulators is the stress mechanic. Every block has two values; strength and weight. The strength of a block determines how much weight it can support. If the block's strength is exceeded, it breaks, usually causing a chain reaction that brings down the entire structure. This means players must focus a lot more on engineering than normal. Building up with a 1-block wide tower will only get you killed as the base collapses, while building a dam is much harder than simply placing dirt in the way. However, blocks placed on a background wall never break, so this mechanic is much less influential than it could be.

Dig or Die's power mechanic is also somewhat unique. Unlike redstone or Terrarian wiring, every circuit in Dig or Die requires an active power source to function. For most of the game, this means solar panels or hydroelectric power plants; no portable or storable power is available until the very end of the game. However, there are a full complement of logic gates, timers, and sensors available to use, so creating an energy-efficient teleporter or automatic airlock is not that difficult.

Once you beat the game, you gain access to the Epilogue, with an infinite Auto-Crafter and Jetpack. This is not creative mode; you do not have invulnerability and enemies will still try to kill you, but with infinite resources it is much easier to take on ambitious projects, like draining the underground ocean, plugging the Volcano or flooding the entire surface.

Overall Dig or Die is extremely well-polished for an Early Access game and is well worth the asking price. I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys Minecraft, Terraria, or games like them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Review.

I really am enjoying this game and it is totally worth the £2 i paid for it. I would definitely say it is well worth the price even now in this early stage. And as such i recommend it to anyone who has similar games and to those who don't. 7/10

The content already in this game is beyond acceptable for the price you pay for it. If the developer was to stop with this project tomorrow i wouldn't at all feel cheated out of my money. I have paid a lot more for a lot less.

The game it self is great. Its same says a lot for the game, you do need to dig or die. The night/day cycle is very well done, making night last a lot less time than day and also make the game very challenging at night.  Took me a couple of attempts to get into the style of play but got the hang of the basics now.

The game needs a tutorial of sorts to get you in the game maybe, as i feel the F1 help a little vague. The only other thing i don't like about the game is the character armour / clothing system. This and sometime the path finding on the enemies is a little less desired.

Overall its a good game and a good price, i look forward to updates in the future. Definitely buy this game.
