reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is essentially a Terraria clone with larger blocks and more water and electricity. It's not bad, and I really love the basic story about crashlanding on a planet and trying to escape it by ultimately building a new space craft. What I don't like is that the game is not very good at following through on that story. The worst are the creatures. They are highly unoriginal, and the AI is just plain dull. I would expect to find aliens, from weird little blobs (they even have those in Terraria) to dino-inspired terrifying bone♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Instead I get... yes, it's true: bees, bats and dogs! And what is it about creatures from all biotopes suddenly narrowing down on you at night (after you attacked them just once)? No matter if you're deep, deep underground or high, high up on a mountain, they all gather just outside the screen boundary to start their relentless onslaught. The fact that even the aforementioned bees, bats and dogs can easily tear down your hard-earned reinforced steel blocks, is just another example of how this games needs more consistency to be taken seriously. It's a treat to build a secure base. It's just so much more annoying to see it fall apart every night. Why bother?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a good game, don't get me wrong, but it's empty.

Pros-
Mining feels nice
Physics
Turrets

Cons-
Blocks are the size of your player, meaning you don't walk over them, you have to jump over them
Almost nothing to do
Base building is annoying, because enemies just destroy your base making ways in
Water is rediculous, no way to remove it, and your breath bar is very small
Physics are very strange, towers collapse too easy, pyramids collapse on themselves when they shouldn't, ect
Enemies are not very varied
Jumping is annoying, character slides, doesn't jump down platforms when told

All in all, it doesn't cost very much, but at the moment, it's not worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's like a single player Terarria that focuses on you fighting off monsters during night time. Unlike Terraria, however, the visuals are fairly weak, the gameplay feels awkward because of the odd physics in the game (why does a plasma rifle knock you back...?), and overall it's not very.. fun. Terraria and other Minecraft spinoffs work because of the multiplayer aspect, or because they make the objective of the game very different from the originals; Dig or Die does neither.

Pros:

- Game progression is much faster than other similar games (Single player vs Multi, I guess)
- Basically no learning curve

Cons:

- The actual gameplay is really boring; not sure if it picks up later, but if I spent 2 hours in the tutorials the tutorials need to be nerfed and progression needs to be sped up
- The inventory takes up half your screen so you can't see jack if you need to pull up stuff in the middle of a fight
- The knockback on guns is stupidly high
- Digging feels like a chore considering it's a SP game
- Progression is completely and totally linear, so it's not actually a rogue-lite
- Something like 7-8 monsters are recycled with palette swaps
- Visuals are pretty bad
- Night defense is kind of silly because you have to build a fort but the monsters can just break your walls
- The weight physics in the game is just wrong
- A lot of other things tbh

3/10 - I think there are some okay concepts in there but really the overall product is just unpolished and needs a complete overhaul. Sure it's in EA, but if the end-game product is anything like it is now, I still won't be able to recommend this.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI can excuse the little amount of content a little bit. But there are many other problems with this game. Games like this get a lot of indie sympathy, which is a little bit deserved, but the game is bad. I seem to be stuck in one part of the game. I have created my house next to two giant lakes that I made for power. I regret this. I can't figure out how to get the power working, or even a reason to have the power. Only 1 thing in the game needs power, so I created a giant tunnel into the hole to the west for no reason. I was just trying to get rid of the water, but it doesn't go down fast enough, so the lakes won't go away. Also, I can't uprage anything. If I go to the right or left I kill the same mosters and stop and the end of the screen. If I go down I can get more interesting stuff, but by then I've killed like 12 mosters, so 200 monsters are chasing me in the underground by nighttime. Then I probably drown in the water, or get killed in a horrible situation. Like the area with the tentacle moster. I died down there once, right after the day started, so I was stuck down there. I get penalized for everything, digging, exploring, expanding. I always drown or die, or kill so many monsters that my base is overun. I can't go up and get the gasrock because I can't go high enough, I can't do ♥♥♥♥ in this game. -69/10. Make it easier.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is an amazing base game with a promsing future of updates. Although there is not much content at the moment, that will be fixed in the future. For now there is still plently of stuff to do. The physics and combat are amazing especially with harder difficulties. And for less than $3.00, you can't get a better game. The developer seems to be dedicated to this game, he plans on adding a little more to the price with each update until it reaches it's planned full price at around $12.00, so clearly he has a long term plan in place. It has no multiplayer yet, but that is such a highly demanded thing by the community that I'm sure it will be. The construction of defenses, bridges, and towers are extremely fun and have a good amount of skill involved in them. There is little grinding in this game, you get straight into the action which I personally enjoy. The developer took everything good about Terraria and other similar games, mashed them together, picked out the bad parts that didn't compliment eachother, and added many unique features and aspects to finish it off. This is a fantastic early access game with a promising future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I picked up 'Dig or Die' on its release date for 2 reasons.  The first reason was the introductory price of $3.00, and the second reason being that it looked like it would be fun.

The game is simplistic in concept:  Explore, Acquire Resources, and prepare defenses for the onset of night.

But that simplistic concept becomes much more challenging as you progress through the various crafting tiers, not to mention the oft-occuring flash flooding.  You begin to not only plan area defense, but also dig strategically placed water drainage ducts and dams.

This game can feel relaxing and safe one moment and then quickly become a frantic struggle for survival the next.   For me it brings to mind that old school classic arcade game Dig Dug.

Dig or Die itself has a cutesie, arcady graphic vibe, but it works just fine for me.

The game, in its current state is very playable, very enjoyable and often fast paced.

As mentioned in other reviews, I agree that it is difficult dealing with the multiple tiered crafting stations. It can be very confusing when it doesn't have to be.  This is most apparent when you are frantically trying to find that recipe you need as you are being swarmed by creatures at night and realize that the crafting station you need as halfway across the world.  - However - with that being said, it does add a strategic element by deciding whether to keep these stations close together, or spread them out between your various attempts at bases - or - just decide if it is worth building duplicate stations at the cost of precious resources.  ;)

In my opinion, with the game as it is in its current state could easily pass muster for a finished game at $7.00 and probably sell decently.   But this game is in early access and therefore in constant development.  I believe that the developer proves that this is a workable game idea which can stand on its own merit and NOT be compared to a Terraria/Starbound clone.  I also believe that the developer knows what he is doing, has a solid roadmap for this game and a bright future is quite probably ensured.

My recommendation is to get this game now at the lower price, rather than waiting, because you know by each of these reviews that this game is definitely heading in the right direction.  Get it at the bargain price now, or just wish you had in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, I would like to congratulate the developer for being one of few that I did not regret buying an early access game from.

Dig or Die is one of the few gems in early access ATM, and it brings something new to the table when it comes to sidescrollers. The goal of the game isn't as simple as many would like to think. First, there's fighting monsters, then digging, then searching for rare plants atop a giant mountain - this game has it all. There are many things about this game that stand out to me as a gamer. One being that the blocks have weight. Though the blocks do not fall over if you hit them, they can and will break if you build them as if you were building in Minecraft. For building large structures, there are blocks you can place to hold up ceilings and other roofs. Another thing is water. You'd think that water wouldn't be a problem, but on the planet you're on, it is a huge one. Forget just digging a hole and covering the entrence to survive, because water will drip from the dirt blocks all around you until you decide to put some actual walls up. And did I mention that enemies can dig, too? Yeah, this game is challenging, but that's where crafting comes in. There are 3 tiers of crafting that are actually well-balanced for being a fairly new game. I'm not going to spoil them for you, but they are categorized by different auto-crafters, each one requires the previous to be made. Each tier also has a new turret(s), allowing you to lock down areas of the map with force. They are also your lifeline at night. The most prevalent mechanic in the game is the day and night cycle. Imagine Dying Light, but 10 times worse (in a challenging way). Enemies are absolutely vicious at night, turning the game from adventuring to tower-defense in a split second. You'll need to think quickly in order to survive away from your base at night, or else its GG for you. Thankfully it auto-saves after every night.

Overall, I give this game an 8/10, even though I usually set my limit on early-access/beta/alpha games at 7/10. With the price set at only $3, you have nothing to lose when trying this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun game, albeit a bit short. I played through on normal, might go back and give harder difficulties a shot. There's a sharp learning curve in the beginning with the physics and enemy AI. Collecting the loot for the early defenses is also tedious. I almost gave up on it honestly, but gave it another shot after watching the trailer, After what was a slow and rocky star, things moved along nicely progression-wise, Totally worth it for the current price tag of $3 and the demand on your system is so low that the game could run on a toaster.

Pros:
- Realistic physics for building structures
- Bridge and tower building was fun
- Smooth combat
- Nice music
- Mining doesn't take ages

Cons:
- Not much to explore
- Little variation for enemies, items and terrain
- Rough, grindy and somewhat confusing start (might just be me)

Noteworthy:
- Surviving nights goes from really hard to really easy, at least on normal difficulty
- Enemy AI was very strange sometimes (a single bee following me across the map for a while, monsters spawning very close to me while digging straight left or right, monsters choosing to dig through an insane amount of ground to get to me)

I'm interested to see how the things fleshed out. As of now, it feels a bit like a section of a bigger game. Fun stuff though, a no brainer to buy and play if you're the terraria/starbound type.

The guns are really good.

Biggest annoyance for me is 1 block high cannot be walked up so you are continuanly jumping for every little height difference in the ground.

*Once underground all monsters should be hostile to varying degrees
*Make water more of a threat
*Make different bridging sections to span gaps more easily
*Put images of the animal you have to find with the item that you need so you know what to look for.

Just a few thoughts, i enjoyed playing but i wouldnt go back now unless it had really changed.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA very basic sandbox survival Terraria
recommended: you name it" like game. Unfinished in content but what is on show at the moment does seem to point to a bright future. The title does have a end game which is crafting a spaceship to get off the alien home world. The crafting involves collecting the usual
hoursPlayed: getting gems from flying bugs and using the workbenches to upgrade items. Its not a overly the top system to use and I got the hang of it early on. What sets it apart from other 2D survival games is the tower defence element which is done rather well.\n\nIt also makes you plan how to go about building bases as there is none of that floating blocks you get in minecraft and if you go over the strengths of the building blocks it will all come falling down about you. Another notable mechanic is that this title does better than most
voteText: is that you never feel that you get large stop gaps in gameplay where you are clueless on what to work towards next. reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like sandbox survival, get this game! It's all about using your resources to defend yourself and escape a foreign planet. There is a huge focus on combat with night survival and base building being circuital in early game. It has great physics, with weight distribution and a water filtration system. (Although many don't like the constant rain, I think It's a great challenge)

Yes it needs many more features, but it is very playable and very enjoyable in its current state, I love the pricing plan too, buy it now for $3.59 NZ ($3 US) now or wait for more content and pay 12. You get you money's worth, and if the game continues, a whole lot more.

Great game, 11/10 - if your still not sure I recommend this let's play by AstralPhaser.

The first time I saw the game, I fell immediately in love with it. Considering the price, you can't really go wrong. And if the price is only going to go up then hey, it's a bargain no matter what you think about it.

I have played the game less then an hour, so I don't really have a really clear opinion about it yet. But I had a lot of fun with it last night and I had to force myself to shut my computer down because it was already two in the morning. The only bug so far that i have experienced is that the keyboard configuratin (azerty to qwerty) suddenly switched around and that the healing potions that I managed to make were all gone before I knew what I was doing. The rain filling things up very quickly is annoying as well but I'm sure that will be fixed eventually.

I will update this review when I have played a few more hours so that my review is taken more seriously.
